oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Infertility and fecundity loss of Wolbachia-infected Aedes aegypti hatched from quiescent eggs is expected to alter invasion dynamics
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lau, Meng-Jia
Ross, Perran A
Hoffmann, Ary A
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Aedes aegypti
invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>The endosymbiotic bacterium <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic> shows viral blocking in its mosquito host, leading to its use in arboviral disease control. Releases with <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic> strains <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>Mel and <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>AlbB infecting <jats:italic>Aedes aegypti</jats:italic> have taken place in several countries. Mosquito egg survival is a key factor influencing population persistence and this trait is also important when eggs are stored prior to releases. We therefore tested the viability of mosquitoes derived from <jats:italic>Wolbachia w</jats:italic>Mel and <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>AlbB-infected as well as uninfected eggs after long-term storage under diurnal temperature cycles of 11–19°C and 22–30°C. Eggs stored at 11–19°C had higher hatch proportions than those stored at 22–30°C. Adult <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic> density declined when they emerged from eggs stored for longer, which was associated with incomplete cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI) when <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>Mel-infected males were crossed with uninfected females. Females from stored eggs at both temperatures continued to show perfect maternal transmission of <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic>, but storage reduced the fecundity of both <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>Mel and <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>AlbB-infected females relative to uninfected mosquitoes. Furthermore, we found a very strong negative impact of the <jats:italic>w</jats:italic>AlbB infection on the fertility of females stored at 22–30°C, with almost 80% of females hatching after 11 weeks of storage being infertile. Our findings provide guidance for storing <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic>-infected <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>aegypti</jats:italic> eggs to ensure high fitness adult mosquitoes for release. Importantly, they also highlight the likely impact of egg quiescence on the population dynamics of <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic>-infected populations in the field, and the potential for <jats:italic>Wolbachia</jats:italic> to suppress mosquito populations through cumulative fitness costs across warm and dry periods, with expected effects on dengue transmission.</jats:p>
